title: Redirect Checker
metaTitle: Free Redirect Checker | Analyze URL Chains & Performance
metaDescription: Check URL redirects instantly. Analyze redirect chains, measure response times, verify 301/302/307/308 status codes, and optimize website performance. Free redirect testing tool.
heroDescription: Check URL redirects quickly. Analyze redirect chains, verify status codes, and measure performance.

children.text: Our redirect checker provides detailed analysis of redirect behavior, status codes, and performance metrics. Whether you're managing a
, changing domains, or optimizing site performance, our tool helps you verify that all redirects are working correctly.
Different redirect types serve different purposes. Our tool detects and analyzes all common redirect types:
: Pass SEO value, used for permanent moves
: Don't pass SEO value, used for temporary changes
: Converts POST to GET, used after form submissions
: Preserves HTTP method, modern alternative to 302
: Preserves HTTP method, modern alternative to 301
, verify all old URLs redirect to their new locations. Test hundreds of URLs at once to ensure no broken links or missing redirects that could harm SEO.

Different platforms handle redirects differently. Use our checker with these platform-specific guides:
: Verify product URL changes and collection redirects
Response Times: Measure redirect performance and latency
Final Destination: Show where each URL ultimately resolves
Redirect Loops: Detect infinite redirect loops before they break your site
HTTPS Transition: Verify HTTP to HTTPS redirects are working
Redirects directly impact your search rankings. Proper implementation preserves SEO value:
Use 301 Redirects: For permanent changes to pass 90-99% of link equity
Avoid Chains: Each hop loses some SEO value and adds latency
Fix Broken Redirects: Redirects to 404 pages waste link equity
Monitor Performance: Slow redirects increase bounce rates

faqs.question: What is a redirect checker and why do I need one?
faqs.answer: A redirect checker analyzes URL redirects to show you redirect chains, status codes, and final destinations. It's essential for troubleshooting redirect issues, verifying proper configuration, and ensuring optimal SEO performance. For testing multiple URLs at once, use our Bulk Redirect Checker tool.

faqs.question: How do I check a redirect?
faqs.answer: Enter a URL into our redirect checker tool and click the check button. Our tool will follow the redirect chain and show you the redirect type, status code, destination URL, response time, and any intermediate hops. For checking multiple URLs simultaneously, use our Bulk Redirect Checker.

faqs.question: What information does a redirect checker provide?
faqs.answer: Our redirect checker shows: HTTP status code (301, 302, 307, 308, etc.), complete redirect chain showing all hops, final destination URL, response time for each redirect, redirect type (permanent vs temporary), and any errors or loops detected. This comprehensive analysis helps you optimize redirect configuration for better performance and SEO.

faqs.question: Can I use this tool to check redirects after a website migration?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is one of the primary use cases. After migrating your website, use our tool to verify that URLs properly redirect to their new locations. For testing multiple URLs from a sitemap, use our Bulk Redirect Checker which can test hundreds of URLs at once to catch missing redirects or incorrect destinations.

faqs.question: What is a redirect chain and why is it bad?
faqs.answer: A redirect chain occurs when URL A redirects to URL B, which redirects to URL C, and so on. Each hop adds 100-200ms latency, slowing page loads. Search engines may stop following chains after 3-5 hops, losing link equity. Chains also waste crawl budget. Use our tool to identify chains and consolidate them into direct redirects (A→C).

faqs.question: How often should I check my redirects?
faqs.answer: Check redirects immediately after any site changes (migrations, platform updates, domain changes). For stable sites, monthly checks of critical URLs suffice. High-traffic sites should check weekly. After major changes, check daily for the first month. Set up automated monitoring for business-critical pages to catch issues immediately.

faqs.question: Will this tool work for WordPress, Shopify, and Wix sites?
faqs.answer: Yes, our redirect checker works with all platforms because it tests URLs directly via HTTP requests, regardless of the platform generating the redirects. Whether your redirects come from WordPress plugins, Shopify's redirect manager, Wix settings, or custom server configuration, our tool detects and analyzes them accurately.

faqs.question: Can I check redirects for shortened URLs like bit.ly?
faqs.answer: Yes, our tool checks all redirects including URL shorteners. For detailed analysis of shortened URLs specifically, use our Short URL Expander tool which reveals the complete redirect chain and final destination for short links from bit.ly, TinyURL, and other services.

faqs.question: When should I use the single vs bulk redirect checker?
faqs.answer: Use our single redirect checker for quick tests or troubleshooting specific pages. It's perfect for debugging individual redirect issues or verifying a particular URL. Use our Bulk Redirect Checker when you need to test hundreds of URLs simultaneously for comprehensive site audits, migrations, or regular monitoring.

faqs.question: How do I fix redirect chains found by the checker?
faqs.answer: When the tool identifies a chain (A→B→C), update your redirect configuration to point directly from A to C, bypassing B. In WordPress, edit the Redirection plugin. In Shopify or Wix, update the redirect manager. For .htaccess, modify the redirect rules. After fixing, retest with our tool to verify the chain is eliminated.
